nodes.bodyText: This seems to be checked very frequently. Would it be better to just do this check once for all the events?
There are also events which doesn't have connection information

Why is this synchronized? I don't like the idea of a thread holding a lock for a prolonged period of time. Also, if all this does is obtain a lock and then wait for another thread to finish, I think it could very easily lead to deadlock if the thread it is waiting on tries to also access something synchronized on this handler.

Serial Handler is implemented to be async, but there is no way to correlate BlueGiga controller request and response messages together. Additionally BlueGiga specs says following "The Application should always wait for the response to a command before issuing another command." So current implementation is fully broken, with these fixes BlueGiga bridge will never issue more than one command at the time.
See #6901
Couldn't you use a single threaded executor to process the transactions?

Introduced unique transaction id per command. Bridge can now send multiple commands without blocking, but only one command is send at the time to BlueGiga controller. Unique transaction id handles correlation between commands and responses.

the removeEventListener method down below isn't synchronized. So either they both need to be synchronized or none (including addEventListener) should be synchronized. Personally, I prefer the latter since I don't see a purpose of synchronizing when the eventListeners are already a CopyOnWriteArraySet, which handle concurrency happily.
Yes you are right, even implementation was already using synchronisations with CopyOnWriteArraySet. Will fix it.

I think this should be a primitive int instead since all the refactored classes expect the primitive as well. You might run into NPEs since most of the code that calls getConnection hasn't taken into account that it can now return nulls.

nodes.bodyText: This doesn't take into account active background discovery, where the user has manually activated a scan for devices to search for things. By always using the config the user will not be able to do a manual scan. You should keep the discoveryActive flag and just update it whenever a manual scan is requested through the scanStart and scanStop methods. You can use org.openhab.binding.bluetooth.bluez.handler.BlueZBridgeHandler for reference.
Good point, but I didn't the change the behaviour, it has been always working like this

A day is a long time for devices to hang around, especially when some of them generate new mac addresses every two minutes. That means you would track and keep memory for over 720+ devices every day. I'm using 5 minutes in Bluez, is there a reason you are tracking it for longer?
Also, you haven't taken into account devices which may have handlers and thus hold a reference to a bluetooth device. If the BlueGigaBridgeHandler loses its reference to that bluetooth device reference then that handler is holding onto a dead device instance that will never receive events until Openhab restarts or the handler is disabled then enabled again.
I solved this problem by adding a hasListeners method to the BluetoothDevice class. It is currently in my PR but I think you would likely need it as well so we need to coordinate on that.

Well, day is not much compared to current implementation where cleanup is not done at all ;) There could also be devices which use static mac, but isn't available all the time, so 5 min cleanup time could be rather aggressive as well.
why intervals of 1.25ms?

always use try/finally for locks
you should have this in a while loop to account for spurious wake-ups.
I would include a ThreadFactory so you can control the name of the thread it produces
Also, I would also use the ThreadFactory to make sure that the thread it produces is a daemon thread.
You can use org.eclipse.smarthome.core.common.NamedThreadFactory for this.

Interrupt doesn't look like a reliable way to terminate the parserThread. In addition to issuing an interrupt, I would close the input and output streams of the parserThread to make sure it gets kicked awake if it is blocking on IO.
If executor is single threaded, how is this timeout ever supposed to run if the single thread is going to be busy with this task? 🤔
Using Thread.sleep is generally frowned upon but I think it would be justified in this case. Add a comment in the code so that other reviewers don't raise (as much of) a fuss.

Rather than constantly cancelling and rescheduling this, why not have it run as a fixed schedule task? Then use locks to make sure that the scheduled task doesn't run when other commands are running. Maybe just synchronize all of the bg* methods?
Expanding on the locks idea, you could use a ReadWriteLock and have all the bg* methods do reads while the passiveScanIdleTimer uses the write lock.

Bridge doesn't know is passive scan is running, so basically bridge should always send command to bluegiga controller when scheduled task is triggered. So it will cause more load than just cancel and rescheduled the timer when commands are send.
But there has to be a way to refactor it better than wrapping everything in try/finally. Could you do it as part of a sendTransaction call?

Is there a better way to do this than a Thread.sleep? Is there an easily checkable condition you can wait for?
Unfortunately no, as we want to wait that controller have stopped sending any frames to the binding and then we can flush the buffer to start frame synchronisation.
I would try to use bulk writes if possible, it would give the underlying OutputStream implementation a chance to optimize if it can, especially if the underlying stream is unbuffered.
I as well, but bluegiga binding use int arrays rather than byte arrays internally, which is rather cumbersome and lead to this kind "issues".

I don't know how well this works, but I can think of much more reliable (albeit more complicated) ways of checking the frame header. Might not be worth addressing now but should probably be noted for later.

Ah, just saw you mentioned this exact piece of code above. In that case, I would suggest changing this code to keep track of a 4 byte window which you shift the buffer one byte at a time. Using a ByteBuffer along with mark/rewind might be worth looking into.
Actually better yet, you could wrap the InputStream in a BufferedInputStream and use its mark/reset functionality.
